Lp spaces

Let S={f∈L1(R3)∣∫f dx=0}S = \set{f \in L^1\p{\R^3} \mid \int f \,\diff{x} = 0}S={f∈L1(R3)∣∫fdx=0}.

  1. Show that SSS is closed in the L1L^1L1 topology.
  2. Show that S∩L2(R3)S \cap L^2\p{\R^3}S∩L2(R3) is a dense subset of L2(R3)L^2\p{\R^3}L2(R3).
Solution.

  1. Let {fn}n⊆S\set{f_n}_n \subseteq S{fn​}n​⊆S be a sequence such that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f in L1L^1L1. Then

    ∣∫f dx∣=∣∫f−fn dx∣≤∥f−fn∥L1→n→∞0,\abs{\int f \,\diff{x}} = \abs{\int f - f_n \,\diff{x}} \leq \norm{f - f_n}_{L^1} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} 0,∣∣​∫fdx∣∣​=∣∣​∫f−fn​dx∣∣​≤∥f−fn​∥L1​n→∞​0,

    so f∈Sf \in Sf∈S.

  2. Compactly supported functions L2L^2L2 functions are dense in L2(R3)L^2\p{\R^3}L2(R3), so it suffices to prove that S∩L2(R3)S \cap L^2\p{\R^3}S∩L2(R3) is dense for such functions.

    Let f∈L2(R3)f \in L^2\p{\R^3}f∈L2(R3) have compact support. Set I=∫f dxI = \int f \,\diff{x}I=∫fdx and R>0R > 0R>0 be such that the support of fff is contained in B(0,R)B\p{0, R}B(0,R). Let σ\sigmaσ denote the surface measure on the unit ball S2S^2S2 so that ∫S2dσ=4π\int_{S^2} \diff\sigma = 4\pi∫S2​dσ=4π. Thus, by polar coordinates,

    m(B(0,a))=∫0a∫S2r2 dσ dr=4πr33.m\p{B\p{0, a}} = \int_0^a \int_{S^2} r^2 \,\diff\sigma \,\diff{r} = \frac{4\pi r^3}{3}.m(B(0,a))=∫0a​∫S2​r2dσdr=34πr3​.

    Fix ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. Set g=fg = fg=f on B(0,R)B\p{0, R}B(0,R) and for R≤∣x∣≤MR \leq \abs{x} \leq MR≤∣x∣≤M (where M>RM > RM>R will be chosen later), let g=−Iεg = -I\epsilong=−Iε (it's only important that ggg has the opposite sign of III on this interval). Then

    ∫g dx=∫f dx−∫B(0,M)∖B(0,R)Iε dx=I−4πIε3(M3−R3).\int g \,\diff{x} = \int f \,\diff{x} - \int_{B\p{0, M} \setminus B\p{0, R}} I\epsilon \,\diff{x} = I - \frac{4\pi I\epsilon}{3}\p{M^3 - R^3}.∫gdx=∫fdx−∫B(0,M)∖B(0,R)​Iεdx=I−34πIε​(M3−R3).

    Pick M=(R3+34πε)1/3M = \p{R^3 + \frac{3}{4\pi\epsilon}}^{1/3}M=(R3+4πε3​)1/3, i.e., so that ∫g dx=0\int g \,\diff{x} = 0∫gdx=0. Thus, g∈Sg \in Sg∈S and because f∈L2(R3)f \in L^2\p{\R^3}f∈L2(R3) and ggg is bounded on R≤∣x∣≤MR \leq \abs{x} \leq MR≤∣x∣≤M, g∈L2(R3)g \in L^2\p{\R^3}g∈L2(R3) as well. Finally,

    ∥f−g∥L22=∫B(0,M)∖B(0,R)I2ε2 dx=m(B(0,M)∖B(0,R))I2ε2=4π(M3−R3)3I2ε2=I2ε.\begin{aligned} \norm{f - g}_{L^2}^2 &= \int_{B\p{0, M} \setminus B\p{0, R}} I^2\epsilon^2 \,\diff{x} \\ &= m\p{B\p{0, M} \setminus B\p{0, R}} I^2\epsilon^2 \\ &= \frac{4\pi\p{M^3 - R^3}}{3} I^2\epsilon^2 \\ &= I^2\epsilon. \end{aligned}∥f−g∥L22​​=∫B(0,M)∖B(0,R)​I2ε2dx=m(B(0,M)∖B(0,R))I2ε2=34π(M3−R3)​I2ε2=I2ε.​

    Since III is independent of ε\epsilonε, we may send ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0, and that gives the claim.
